question: Why would a company like Apple be buying back its own shares?
human_answers: I think JB King's answer is interesting from the point of view of "is this good for me" but the OP's question boils down to "why would a company do this?" The company buys back shares when it thinks it will better position the company financially. A Simple Scenario: If Company A wants to open a new store, for example, they need to buy the land, build the store, stock it, etc, etc and this all costs money.  The company can get a loan, use accrued capital, or raise new capital by issuing new stock.  Each method has benefits and drawbacks. One of the drawbacks of issuing new stock is that it dilutes the existing stock's value.  Previously, total company profits were split between x shares.  Now the profits are shared between x+y shares, where y is the number of new shares issued to raise the capital. This normally drives the price of the stock down, since the expected future dividends per stock have decreased. Now the company has a problem: the next time they go to raise money by issuing stock, they will have to issue MORE shares to get the same value - leading to more dilution.  To break out of this cycle, the company can buy back shares periodically.  When the company feels the the stock is sufficiently undervalued, it buys some back.  Now the profits are shared with a smaller pool, and the stock price goes up, and the next time Company A needs to raise capital, it can issue stock. So it probably has little to do with rewarding shareholders, and more to do with lowering the "cost of capital" for the company in the future.
chatgpt_answers: There are a few reasons why a company like Apple might buy back its own shares:To increase the value of the remaining shares: When a company buys back its own shares, it reduces the total number of outstanding shares on the market. This can lead to an increase in the value of the remaining shares, as each share represents a larger portion of the company's ownership.To return value to shareholders: Some companies use share buybacks as a way to return value to shareholders, especially when they have excess cash on hand and do not have any immediate plans for it. Share buybacks can be a way for companies to distribute profits to shareholders without actually paying dividends.To improve financial ratios: Buying back shares can also improve a company's financial ratios, such as its price-to-earnings ratio and its earnings per share. This can make the company more attractive to investors and potentially increase the value of its stock.To reduce the risk of a hostile takeover: By buying back its own shares, a company can make it more difficult for another company or individual to gain a controlling stake in the company. This can help the company maintain its independence and protect itself from a hostile takeover.

question: Are the guaranteed returns of regulated utilities really what they sound like?
human_answers: No. That return on equity number is a target that the regulators consider when approving price hikes. If PG&E tried to get a 20% RoE, the regulator would deny the request. Utilities are basically compelled to accept price regulation in return for a  monopoly on utility business in a geographic area. There are obviously no guarantees that a utility will make money, but these good utilities are good stable investments that generally speaking will not make you rich, but appreciate nicely over time. Due to deregulation, however, they are a more complex investment than they once were. Basically, the utility builds and maintains a bunch of physical infrastructure, buys fuel and turns it into electricity. So they have fixed costs, regulated pricing, market-driven costs for fuel, and market-driven demand for electricity.  Also consider that the marginal cost of adding capacity to the electric grid is incredibly high, so uneven demand growth or economic disruption in the utility service area can hurt the firms return on equity (and thus the stock price). Compare the stock performance of HE (the Hawaiian electric utlity) to ED (Consolidated Edison, the NYC utility) to SO (Southern Companies, the utility for much of the South). You can see that the severe impact of the recession on HE really damaged the stock -- location matters. Buying strategy is key as well -- during bad market conditions, money flows into these stocks (which are considered to be low-risk "defensive" investments) and inflates the price. You don't want to buy utilities at a peak... you need to dollar-cost average a position over a period of years and hold it. Focus on the high quality utilities or quality local utilities if you understand your local market. Look at Southern Co, Progress Energy, Duke Energy or American Electric Power as high-quality benchmarks to compare with other utilities.
chatgpt_answers: Regulated utilities are companies that provide essential services such as electricity, gas, and water to the public. These companies are typically regulated by government agencies, which set the rates that the utilities can charge for their services. The rates are usually set at a level that allows the utilities to recover their costs, including the cost of financing their operations, and to earn a reasonable return on their investment.The guaranteed returns that regulated utilities may receive are often referred to as "allowed returns" or "authorized returns." These returns are intended to compensate the utilities for the risks they take in providing essential services to the public and to ensure that they have the financial resources they need to maintain and improve their infrastructure.The allowed returns for regulated utilities may be based on a number of factors, including the cost of capital, the level of risk involved in providing the service, and the level of competition in the market. In some cases, the allowed returns may be set through a process known as rate-making, in which the regulatory agency considers the utilities' costs and revenue requirements and sets the rates accordingly.It's important to note that the allowed returns for regulated utilities are not guaranteed, as they may be adjusted based on changes in the economic conditions or the utilities' performance. However, the regulatory process is designed to provide a degree of stability and predictability for the utilities, which can help them plan and invest in the long term.

The expiration date is the last day on which the option can be exercised. The holder of a call option has the right to buy the underlying asset, while the holder of a put option has the right to sell the underlying asset. The underlying asset can be a variety of financial instruments, such as stocks, bonds, currencies, commodities, or futures contracts.

question: How to Calculate Profit and Loss for trading position?
human_answers: Month to date For the month to date (MTD), the price on Feb 28th is $4.58 and the price on March 16th is $4.61 so the return is which can be written more simply as The position is 1000 shares valued at $4580 on Feb 28th, so the profit on the month to date is Calendar year to date For the calendar year to date (YTD), the price on Dec 31st is $4.60 and the price on Feb 28th is $4.58 so the return to Feb 28th is The return from Feb 28th to March 16th is 0.655022 % so the year to date return is or more directly So the 2011 YTD profit on 1000 shares valued at $4600 on Dec 31st is Year to date starting Dec 10th For the year to date starting Dec 10th, the starting value is and the value on Dec 31st is 1000 * $4.60 = $4600 so the return is $4600 / $4510 - 1 = 0.0199557 = 1.99557 % The year to date profit is therefore Note - YTD is often understood to mean calendar year to date.  To cover all the bases state both, ie "calendar YTD (2011)" and "YTD starting Dec 10th 2010". Edit further to comment For the calendar year to date, with 200 shares sold on Jan 10th with the share price at $4.58, the return from Dec 31st to Jan 10th is The return from Jan 10th to Feb 28th is The return from Feb 28th to March 16th is The profit on 1000 shares from Dec 31st to Jan 10th is $4600 * -0.00434783 = -$20 The profit on 800 shares from Jan 10th to Feb 28th is zero. The profit on 800 shares from Feb 28th to March 16th is So the year to date profit is $4.
chatgpt_answers: To calculate the profit or loss for a trading position, you will need to know the following information:The entry price: This is the price at which you opened the trade (bought or sold) the security.The exit price: This is the price at which you closed the trade (bought or sold) the security.The size of the trade: This is the number of units of the security that you bought or sold.To calculate the profit or loss, you will need to subtract the entry price from the exit price, and then multiply the result by the size of the trade. If the result is positive, you have made a profit; if it is negative, you have made a loss.For example, let's say you bought 100 shares of a stock at a price of $50 per share, and then sold them at a price of $60 per share. The profit on the trade would be ($60 - $50) * 100 = $1000.On the other hand, if you had sold the shares at a price of $40 per share, the loss on the trade would be ($40 - $50) * 100 = -$1000.It's important to note that these calculations do not take into account any commissions or fees that you may have paid to execute the trade. You will need to subtract these costs from your profit or add them to your loss to get the true profit or loss on the trade.

question: Q. What do right bundle branch block and mild mitral regurgitation mean?Hello doctor,My 18-year-old son got an ECG and blood tests last month as a requirement for medical screening. He jogs every night for 30 minutes. He looks healthy. We consulted our cardiologist early this month and he requested for 2D Echo and treadmill stress test. chatgpt_answers:
Right bundle branch block (RBBB) is a type of heart block that occurs when there is a delay or obstruction in the electrical signals that coordinate the contraction of the right side of the heart. It can be caused by a variety of factors, including scarring of the heart tissue, inflammation, or abnormalities in the heart's structure.

Mild mitral regurgitation (MR) refers to a condition in which the mitral valve, which separates the left atrium and left ventricle of the heart, does not close properly. As a result, some of the blood that has been pumped from the left ventricle leaks back into the left atrium, instead of being pumped out to the rest of the body. Mild MR is generally considered to be a mild form of the condition, in which the leakage of blood is minimal.

It is important to note that the presence of RBBB and mild MR does not necessarily mean that your son has a serious heart condition. However, it is important to follow up with your cardiologist and undergo any recommended tests or procedures to determine the cause and appropriate treatment, if necessary. It is also important for your son to continue to follow a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, a healthy diet, and avoiding tobacco and excess alcohol, to support the health of his heart.

Bonding: If your teeth have only shifted slightly, you may be able to correct their position using dental bonding. This involves applying a composite resin material to your teeth and sculpting it into the desired shape. Whiteheads, also known as closed comedones, are a type of acne that form when oil and dead skin cells clog hair follicles. They can appear anywhere on the body, but are commonly found on the face, particularly the chin and around the lips.

There are several steps you can take to help clear or lessen the appearance of whiteheads:

Keep your skin clean: Wash your face twice a day with a mild, oil-free cleanser to remove excess oil and dirt. Avoid scrubbing your skin, as this can irritate it and make the problem worse.

Use salicylic acid: This is a type of beta hydroxy acid that helps to exfoliate the skin and unclog pores. Look for products that contain salicylic acid, such as face washes or toners, and use them as directed.

Use a non-comedogenic moisturizer: Choose a moisturizer that is specifically designed for acne-prone skin and won't clog pores. Look for products that are labeled "non-comedogenic" or "oil-free."

Avoid touching your face: Hands can transfer bacteria and oil to the skin, so it's important to avoid touching your face as much as possible.

Avoid picking or squeezing whiteheads: This can cause inflammation and may lead to scarring. If you do need to extract a whitehead, make sure to do it gently and with clean hands and tools.

Use a gentle exfoliant: Gently exfoliating your skin can help to remove dead skin cells and unclog pores. Look for products that contain alpha hydroxy acids (AHAs) or beta hydroxy acids (BHAs).

Use a spot treatment: If you have a single whitehead that you need to treat, you can use a spot treatment that contains benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid. These products can help to kill bacteria and dry out the whitehead.

It's important to remember that it can take time and patience to clear up whiteheads. If you have tried these steps and your whiteheads are still not improving, it may be a good idea to see a dermatologist for further evaluation and treatment.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a chronic mental health condition that can cause significant distress and disrupt daily life. It is characterized by obsessions, which are unwanted and intrusive thoughts, images, or urges that cause anxiety or distress, and compulsions, which are repetitive behaviors or mental acts that a person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession.

Treatment for OCD often involves a combination of medications and therapy. Fluoxetine, which is a type of antidepressant called a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is often used to treat OCD. SSRIs work by increasing the levels of serotonin, a chemical messenger in the brain that is involved in mood and behavior.

While there is no known "cure" for OCD, treatment can be very effective in reducing symptoms and improving quality of life. It is important to work with a mental health professional, such as a psychiatrist or psychologist, to determine the best treatment plan for you. Therapy options for OCD include cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and exposure and response prevention (ERP), which have been shown to be effective in treating OCD.

It is not uncommon for people with OCD to need long-term treatment to manage their symptoms. However, it is possible for some people to eventually taper off or stop taking medication or to reduce the frequency of therapy sessions. It is important to work closely with your treatment team and follow their recommendations for care.

Arthritis: Inflammation of the joints can cause stiffness and discomfort in the hands, particularly in the morning.

Repetitive Strain Injury (RSI): Repetitive hand movements, such as typing or using a mouse, can lead to swelling and inflammation in the tendons and muscles of the hand, resulting in numbness and stiffness.

Pinched nerves: Nerves can become pinched or compressed anywhere along their path, leading to numbness and tingling in the affected area.

AFB stands for acid-fast bacilli, which are a type of bacterium that includes Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB). The AFB test is a laboratory test that is used to detect the presence of AFB in a sample of bodily fluids or tissue. A positive result means that AFB were detected in the sample, while a negative result means that no AFB were detected.

PCR stands for polymerase chain reaction, which is a laboratory technique that is used to amplify small amounts of DNA. It can be used to detect the presence of M. tuberculosis in a sample, even when other methods, such as the AFB test, are negative. A positive PCR result for M. tuberculosis means that the bacterium was detected in the sample.

If you have been diagnosed with AFB negative but PCR for M.tuberculosis positive, it means that the AFB test did not detect the presence of AFB in your sample, but the PCR test did detect the presence of M. tuberculosis DNA. This suggests that you may have a TB infection. It is important to follow the treatment recommendations of your healthcare provider in order to properly treat the infection and prevent it from spreading to others.

chatgpt_answers:
There are several treatment options for a kidney stone in the interpolar region of the right kidney. The best option for you will depend on the size and location of the stone, as well as your overall health and medical history. Some common treatment options include:

Medications: Your doctor may prescribe medications to help you pass the kidney stone more easily. These may include medications to help relax the muscles in your ureter (the tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder), or medications to help break down the stone.

Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): This is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break the kidney stone into smaller pieces, which can then pass more easily through the urinary tract.

Ureteroscopy: This is a procedure in which a small, flexible tube with a light and camera on the end is inserted through the urethra and up into the urinary tract. The doctor can then use instruments to remove the kidney stone or break it up into smaller pieces.

Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL): This is a surgical procedure in which a small incision is made in the back, and a tube is inserted through the incision and into the kidney to remove the stone.

Open surgery: In some cases, open surgery may be necessary to remove a large or complex kidney stone. This involves making a larger incision in the abdomen to access the stone and remove it.

Your doctor will discuss the best treatment options for you based on the size and location of your kidney stone, as well as your overall health and medical history. It's important to follow your doctor's recommendations and take any prescribed medications as directed to help manage your kidney stone and prevent future stones from forming.

question: Is heart palpitation interconnected to blood in stool?I have been suffering from heart palpitations for more than 3 years, but now they have gotten worse i-e 120-140 bpm with a simplest activity (standing,walking etc). human_answers: Dear Patient,      Thank you very much for your question. According to American heart association, normal healthy heart rate is 60-100 beats per minute when you are relaxed and not engaged in a physical activity. If your heart rate is 100 bpm or above while you are resting and relaxed it is called as tachycardia. However, If you engage in any physical activity your heart rate can race up. That is normal.  Subtracting your age from 220 you can find out your maximum heart rate. For instance, If you are 50 years old, your maximum heart rate is 220-50= 170 bpm. Anyway in your condition, I would recommend that you consult your family doctor for a physical examination and proper consultation. I am sure your family doctor will direct you to a  normal ECG test and stress ECG or exercise ECG test to rule out some pathologies appearing during physical activities. Also he or she may direct you to a holter monitor test if necessary to rule out some arrhythmias.  Conditions like atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter can cause very high pulse rate like yours and sometimes for that cause is hyperthyroidism. Therefore, you might need to check your thyroid function too.               Concerning your blood in stool, I think it might be as a result of gastrointestinal pathology and I hardly believe it is  related to your high pulse rate.Also I want to ask you the color of blood you noticed on your stool. Red color fresh blood on stool can be due to hemorrhoids or due to hard stool passage  while black stool can be as a result of hemorrhage due to ulcer disease, ulcerative colitis etc.  In order to diagnose these conditions, again you have to do a stool test and explain all other symptoms you have. Well-known ports: These are ports that are reserved for specific services and are usually associated with well-known internet protocols, such as HTTP (port 80), HTTPS (port 443), and FTP (port 21).

question: how does weather happen

Weather is the state of the atmosphere at a particular place and time, including temperature, humidity, cloud cover, and wind conditions. It is caused by a combination of factors, including the Earth's rotation, the movement of air masses, the Earth's distance from the sun, and the Earth's surface features.

One of the main factors that drives weather is the Earth's rotation on its axis, which causes different parts of the Earth to receive more or less solar radiation at different times of the year. This is what causes the seasons.

Another important factor is the movement of air masses. Air masses are large bodies of air that have similar temperature and humidity characteristics. These air masses can move from one place to another, bringing different weather conditions with them. For example, an air mass that is warm and moist will bring with it a period of warm, humid weather, while an air mass that is cold and dry will bring cooler, dry weather.

The Earth's distance from the sun also plays a role in the weather. The Earth is closest to the sun in January and farthest from the sun in July. This difference in distance from the sun affects the amount of solar radiation that the Earth receives, which in turn affects the temperature and weather patterns.

Finally, the Earth's surface features, such as mountains, oceans, and forests, can also influence the weather. For example, mountains can block the movement of air masses, causing weather patterns to change as the air masses move around the obstacles. Similarly, oceans can store heat and release it slowly over time, which can affect the temperature and humidity of the air masses that pass over them.

question: what are the three ossicles

The three ossicles are small bones in the middle ear that play a vital role in hearing. They are called the malleus (hammer), the incus (anvil), and the stapes (stirrup). These bones are connected to each other and to the eardrum and inner ear by a series of ligaments and muscles.

The malleus is the largest of the ossicles and is attached to the eardrum. When sound waves reach the eardrum, they cause it to vibrate, which in turn causes the malleus to move.

question: when did classification of races begin

Classification of races, or the categorization of human populations into distinct groups based on physical or biological traits, has a long history that dates back to ancient civilizations. The concept of race as we understand it today, however, has its roots in the European exploration and colonization of the Americas, Africa, and Asia. During this period, European scientists and philosophers sought to understand and classify the diversity of human populations they encountered, and they used various physical and cultural characteristics to create categories or "races." This process was often motivated by a desire to justify European colonialism and the exploitation of non-European peoples.

In the 19th and early 20th centuries, the concept of race was further developed and codified by scientists and scholars who sought to use biological and genetic characteristics to define racial categories. These efforts were often driven by a belief in the superiority of certain racial groups and the use of scientific terminology and methods to support these beliefs.

Today, the concept of race is still used in various contexts, but it is widely recognized that it is a social construct rather than a scientifically valid way of categorizing human populations. Many scientists and scholars argue that race has no biological basis and that it is a product of social, cultural, and political factors.

question: what is "thin film" technology

Thin film technology refers to the process of depositing a thin layer of material onto a substrate or base material. This thin layer can range from a few nanometers to a few micrometers in thickness, and is typically applied using techniques such as physical vapor deposition, chemical vapor deposition, or sputtering.

Thin films are used in a wide range of applications, including electronics, optics, energy storage, and sensors. In electronics, thin films are used to create thin film transistors (TFTs), which are used in LCD displays and other electronic devices. In optics, thin films are used to create coatings for lenses and other optical components to improve their performance. In energy storage, thin films are used to create thin film batteries and supercapacitors. In sensors, thin films are used to create thin film sensors that can detect various types of stimuli, such as temperature, pressure, and humidity.

There are several advantages to using thin film technology. Thin films can be applied to a wide range of materials, including metals, semiconductors, and insulators. They can also be applied to flexible and/or irregularly shaped substrates, which makes them useful for a variety of applications. In addition, thin films can be applied using relatively simple and low-cost processes, which makes them an attractive option for mass production.

question: how is rfid tag powered
human_answers: Some tags are powered and read at short ranges (a few meters) via magnetic fields ( electromagnetic induction ).Others use a local power source such as a battery, or else have no battery but collect energy from the interrogating EM field, and then act as a passive transponder to emit microwaves or UHF radio waves (i.e., electromagnetic radiation at high frequencies).Battery powered tags may operate at hundreds of meters.
chatgpt_answers:
RFID tags can be powered in a few different ways:

Passive RFID tags: These tags do not have their own power source and are activated by the radio frequency energy transmitted by the RFID reader. The energy from the reader is used to power the microchip in the tag and transmit the stored data back to the reader.

Active RFID tags: These tags have their own power source, usually a small battery, which is used to power the microchip and transmit the stored data to the reader.

Semi-passive RFID tags: These tags have a small battery that is used to power the microchip, but the tag is still activated by the radio frequency energy transmitted by the reader. The energy from the reader is used to amplify the signal from the tag's microchip, allowing it to be read at a greater distance.

Overall, the power source for an RFID tag depends on the specific type of tag and the intended application.

question: What would happen if a syringe of water was injected into your veins ? Say you were prepping for surgery , what would happen if instead of anaesthetic , you were injected with water , in both small quantities and say a syringe full or more ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: If plain water were injected into a vein it would dilute the contents of the plasma ( mainly electrolytes like sodium and chloride , and proteins ) in that local area . Through a process called osmosis a portion of the water would fairly rapidly be drawn into nearby cells , in particular the red blood cells . Many of these cells would expand in volume rapidly to the point that their cell membranes would rupture , spilling their contents into the circulation . For a very small amount of water there would be no lasting harm . As the amount increases more red cells would be damaged . The harm from this falls into two categories - as you lose red blood cells , your blood is less able to carry oxygen to other parts of the body , and the substances leaking from the injured cells would in large enough quantities cause harm themselves since the balance of what is kept inside and outside of these cells is delicate and well regulated . If , instead of plain water , water with solutes in roughly the same concentration as the plasma was introduced ( such as " normal saline " ) , and the quantities were not ridiculous , then it would simply become part of your circulating blood volume . Over time the extra fluid would end up dividing between your circulating blood volume , the insides of various cells , and the fluid that surrounds cells in your body outside of the circulation . This scenario is common - for example , small volumes of saline are usually used to flush medications given through an intravenous line in order to make sure all of it enters the blood at the time it was intended to be given .
chatgpt_answers: If a syringe of water were injected into your veins, it would not be harmful in small quantities. This can lead to a condition called hyponatremia, which occurs when the sodium levels in your blood become too low. Symptoms of hyponatremia include headache, nausea, vomiting, seizures, and even coma or death in severe cases. It is important to always follow your doctor's instructions and use medications as directed to avoid any potential harm.

question: Arguments for and against The Federal Reserve . I know there are some politicians who want to dismantle it while others see it being vital for the nation . I want to better understand both sides of the argument . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: I 'll take the " pro - federal reserve " side of the question , I 'll let somebody else handle the anti - federal - reserve side . So let 's say there 's three guys on an island , Fred the Farmer , Tom the Tailor , and Chad the Carpenter . But today , they have a problem . Fred needs clothes from Tom . Tom needs his roof fixed by Chad . Chad needs some food from Fred . Unfortunately , when Fred bumps into Tom , they fail to make a deal , because Tom needs Chad 's help , not Fred 's help . That 's the problem with " barter , " which is direct trading . If you bump into somebody , and they have exactly what you need , unless you also have exactly what they need , you ca n't make a deal ! The likelihood that two people will bump into each other , and they both have exactly what the other person needs , is pretty slim . These three guys , together , have everything they need . But they ca n't organize a trade . So that 's why money exists : to help people trade . Let 's say they get together and make three " dollars " using three slips of paper and a green pen . They each get a dollar , and they each agree that they 'll accept a dollar for whatever it is they do . Now here 's what happens : Fred bumps into Tom , and buys clothes for a dollar . Then , Tom bumps into Chad and buys a roof repair for a dollar . Then , Chad bumps into Fred , and buys food for a dollar . Now everyone has what they need . Interestingly , everyone still has a dollar . Now for a while , life is good . The three of them buy thousands of dollars worth of stuff from each other , using their three bills . This is possible because when you use dollars , they 're not used up - they just circulate . Each bill can be used over and over . But one day , a new person , Mary , lands on the island . She has a ship full of video games , food and clothes . And she lives on her ship ! So she does n't need anything from these three guys at all . But she 's nice , so she offers a video game each to Tom , Chad , and Fred . She accepts a dollar from each of them , even though she does n't really need Fred 's food , Tom 's clothes , or Chad 's repairs . She figures she 'll hold onto the dollars , because maybe she 'll want sexual favors later . Now Mary has three dollars , and the other guys have nothing . Then , all of a sudden , Fred needs clothes from Tom again . Tom needs his roof fixed by Chad again . Chad needs some food from Fred again . But Mary has all the dollars ! So they go to Mary , and they try to get some dollars from her . But Mary has everything she needs . She still has a ship full of video games , her home is in great shape , her clothes are nice , and her fridge is full of food . She thanks the guys for the kind offer , but she decides to keep the three dollars in case she needs them later . She 's not being mean , she 's just being sensible . But Fred , Tom , and Chad are in a bind . Fred , Tom , and Chad want to trade with each other . They have plenty of stuff : Fred still has food , Tom still has clothes , and Chad still can fix houses . But they have no dollars . They vaguely remember that it 's possible to trade without dollars , and they consider going back to the barter system . But that 's a bad idea . If they 're smart , they 'll get out their paper and green pen again . It would be silly for them to go back to barter , when they have a better way . When this whole thing started , they just made the dollars . They can do it again , and they 'd be foolish not to . Mary will be angry , because she gave up three video games for her three dollars , and the three guys will just be making dollars " for free " using paper and pen . She has a point . She correctly thinks that her three dollars might be seen as less valuable , if they are n't the only dollars around . But it 's also not reasonable for Mary to expect Fred , Tom , and Chad to go back to the barter system . They need to compromise . The Federal Reserve 's job is to balance those two needs against each other . Chad , Fred , and Tom need to have enough dollars to be able to trade without bartering , but then again , the reserve should n't make so many dollars that Mary 's money becomes worthless . Now , some people think there should n't be a federal reserve . In that case , Mary would have the dollars , and that would be that . Fred , Chad , and Tom would have to go back to bartering with each other .
chatgpt_answers: Sure! The Federal Reserve, also known as the "Fed," is the central bank of the United States. It is responsible for implementing monetary policy, which is the way that the government and the Fed try to control the supply of money and credit in the economy in order to achieve certain goals like low unemployment and stable prices. Here are some arguments for and against the Fed: FOR: The Fed helps to stabilize the economy by using tools like setting interest rates and controlling the money supply to try to keep prices stable and unemployment low. The Fed can act as a "lender of last resort" by providing loans to banks during times of financial crisis, which can help to prevent or mitigate severe economic downturns. The Fed is independent of political influence, which some people argue makes it better able to make decisions that are in the best interest of the economy as a whole, rather than being swayed by short-term political considerations. AGAINST: Some people argue that the Fed has too much power and that it is not accountable to the public. They may also argue that the Fed's decisions can have negative consequences, such as causing asset bubbles or leading to high inflation. Some people believe that the Fed is secretive and that it is not transparent about its decision-making processes. Some people argue that the Fed is not necessary and that the government should be responsible for regulating the money supply and setting interest rates. They may also argue that the Fed's actions can lead to inequities, such as benefiting certain groups or industries over others. Overall, there are valid arguments on both sides of the debate about the role and effectiveness of the Federal Reserve. It is up to each individual to decide which arguments they find most persuasive.

question: What exactly is Supply Chain Management ? I understand I think the basics , but could you for example , explain to me how it would work for a restaurant ? Or a grocery store ? Or even something simpler , like a Game Stop . Thank you . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: SCM is all about how a company provides its goods / services . In simple terms , if you visualize a company as a sequence of steps , supply chain is about how the steps link up . e.g. For gamestop . They need to buy the games from publishers They need to distribute the games to each store across the country They need to stock them on shelves appropriately They need to sell them to customers They need to restock the items ( this starts the process again ) SCM is about making sure that process is as smooth as possible . I.e. there is always stock available when needed , it does nt take too long in shipment , the delivery process is simple , making sure they do n't order too many items that they will need to discount , etc
chatgpt_answers: Supply chain management is the process of organizing the flow of goods and services from the point of origin to the point of consumption. It involves managing the movement and storage of raw materials, work-in-process inventory, and finished goods from one place to another. In a restaurant, supply chain management would involve ordering ingredients and other supplies, such as dishes and utensils, from suppliers and coordinating their delivery to the restaurant. It would also involve managing the storage of these supplies in the restaurant's pantry, fridge, and freezer, as well as keeping track of inventory levels to ensure there is enough of everything to meet the demand of customers. In a grocery store, supply chain management would involve ordering products from manufacturers and wholesalers and coordinating their delivery to the store. It would also involve managing the storage of these products in the store's warehouse and on the shelves, as well as keeping track of inventory levels to ensure there is a sufficient supply of products for customers. In a Game Stop, supply chain management would involve ordering video games and other gaming products from manufacturers and distributors and coordinating their delivery to the store. It would also involve managing the storage of these products in the store's warehouse and on the shelves, as well as keeping track of inventory levels to ensure there is a sufficient supply of products for customers. Overall, the goal of supply chain management is to ensure that the right products are available to customers at the right time and in the right place, while also minimizing costs and maximizing efficiency.

question: In a motorcycle transmission , why is Neutral almost always between 1st and 2nd gear ? and why is n't it before 1st , would n't that make more sense ? Explain like I'm five.

Neutral is usually between 1st and 2nd gear because it's a place where the engine's RPM is usually low enough that it won't stall, but high enough that you can easily shift into 1st or 2nd gear when you want to start moving again.

question: How do audio and video codecs work , and why do we need them ? I 'd like to gain a basic understanding of audio and video codecs . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Do you want to know about the theory behind them , or about which ones are better in which situations and how to use them ? Video is a series of still images ( called * frames * ) played rapidly in a row . Most commonly , people will use 24 frames per second ( * 24fps * ) for video ; that 's 24 still images played quickly enough that it seems like smooth motion . Each of these images is made up from many tiny coloured squares , called * pixels * . Think of a [ mosaic art piece ] ( URL_0 ) ; the more pieces of mosaic -- pixels -- you use , the more detailed the image can be . The number of pixels used in an image is called its * resolution * . To illustrate the differences in resolution : a DVD has 345,600 pixels per frame , HDTV has around 921,000 , and Blu - ray has over 2 million . For every second of video you see on a Bluray , the player is putting 49.76 million tiny coloured squares on the screen in a specific order . That 's a * lot * of information . The player would have to say " Put a red square first . Then a blue square . Then a yellow square . Then a green square " to the TV almost 50 million times a second . When it 's speaking in plain English like that , just saying what squares go where , we call it * uncompressed video * . Uncompressed Blu - ray video takes up 149.3 megabytes per second ( without even counting audio ) . * Codecs * are our solution to that problem . They * encode * the video -- that is , they turn that list of " Put red square here " plain - English instructions into a special kind of code that 's a lot faster and takes less space to store . They will also change parts of the video to make it easier to describe in this code . One trick they might use is to keep non - moving portions of the screen static . Imagine your video is a Simpsons episode where Homer is mowing the lawn . Your uncompressed video , which does n't use a codec , will describe every single part of the scene 24 times per second , using a LOT of space . You use a clever codec that says " Oh , look -- * Homer and the lawnmower * are moving , but the house stays perfectly still in the background . We 'll describe the house once , and just say * keep that on the screen for 10 seconds * , so we do n't have to keep describing it over and over . " You 've saved a lot of space that way . Likewise , while your uncompressed video describes Homer 's face as " yellow pixel , then yellow pixel , then yellow pixel , then yellow pixel " over and over again a million times , your clever new codec would say " Repeat yellow pixel 500 times " , saving space . It might even say , depending on what codec you 've chosen and what settings it has , " That tree in the background is made up of 500 shades of green , but let 's trim that down to 300 shades , it wo n't look that much different but it 'll save some more space . " After enough of these tricks , your 900 GB video is down to 8 GB , small enough to put on a DVD . Why are there so many different codecs ? Well , it takes a lot of computer brainpower to process a video using an advanced codec . Back in 1990 , when computers were slow and computers were just starting out , they would 've made quite simple codecs that did n't take a million years for the computer to understand . Now in 2011 , because our computers are hundreds of times faster , we can write new codecs that employ very in - depth and complicated tricks . Our priorities have also changed -- now that we can stream videos online without worry , and now that we have 2 TB hard drives instead of 2 GB ones , we prefer to have big - but - pretty videos , while 1990s folks wanted to keep them as small as they possibly could . The codec used on DVDs is called MPEG-2 . MPEG-2 dates from 1996 , and was written with the goal of being decoded by cheap , low - power DVD players , so it 's not very thorough or clever . The codec used on Blu - ray , iTunes video and many online sites is called H.264 or AVC . It is much newer , and was written knowing that it would be used on the strong computers of the late 2000s , rather than low - power devices from the mid-90s . As such , it is much smarter and more powerful -- because it knows it 'll be played by powerful processors -- and provides a much higher quality of video . If you yourself are looking to encode video , the three most popular codec formats are * * MPEG-2 * * ( used only for DVDs nowadays ) , * * Xvid * * ( used in the AVI files you find online , good for making sure everyone can see it , or that it can be played on phones and other low - power devices ) and * * H.264 * * ( used for most online , Blu - ray , and HD videos ; the best choice in 95 % of cases ) . Now , as a footnote , let 's note what a * container format * is . Many people are confused by this . Containers are things like AVI , MKV , or MP4 . These file extensions do not tell you what codec was used to make the video . Think of them more like ZIP files . Most video files contain the video , one or two audio tracks , maybe some subtitles , and some chapters . Each of those things is a separate piece , in a different format , messily separated . So you put them together into a * container * , one file that contains them all , just like ZIP . The exact same video can be represented inside an AVI , an MKV , or an MP4 , but they have different features . For example , AVI is 20 years old , made specially for Windows , and only really supports one video with one piece of audio on the top -- but everyone can view it . MKV is more modern , and supports multiple viewing angles , chapters like a DVD , built - in subtitles , multiple audio tracks ( so you can embed director 's commentary or different languages ) , but because it 's relatively modern , older software does n't know how to deal with it . When you make a video , you choose what container you want based on your needs , but it has absolutely zero effect on the image quality , and it is very easy to change later . For example , today I made a file where the video format was H.264 , the audio format was MP3 , the subtitle format was SRT , and the container format was MKV . That 's an MKV file , but the * video * is n't MKV , it 's H.264 . MKV 's just the container I put all the stuff in .
chatgpt_answers: Sure! An audio codec is a piece of software that is used to compress and decompress audio files. Audio files, like songs or recordings of people talking, can be very large, so codecs are used to make them smaller and easier to store or transmit. Video codecs work in a similar way, but they are used to compress and decompress video files. Video files, like movies or TV shows, can be even larger than audio files, so codecs are especially important for storing and transmitting them. We need audio and video codecs because it's not practical to store or transmit large audio and video files without compressing them first. For example, it would take a long time to download a movie over the internet if it wasn't compressed with a codec first. Codecs allow us to store and transmit audio and video more efficiently.

question: how do computers generate random numbers ? What are the common methods , and how truly random are numbers generated by a computer ? Explain like I'm five.

Pseudo random numbers are numbers that follow the randomness of true random numbers , but are to some extent predictable . Scientists , programmers , take one or more variables that are different every time you would want a random number . Most logical would be to take time or something related to time . Computers use algorithms, or sets of instructions, to generate random numbers. These algorithms take in a starting number, called a seed, and use it to create a sequence of numbers that appears random.

One common method for generating random numbers is called the linear congruential generator. This method uses a formula to generate a new number based on the previous number in the sequence. The new number is called a pseudorandom number because it appears random, but it is actually generated using a formula.

Another method for generating random numbers is called the Mersenne Twister. This method uses a more complex formula to generate a sequence of pseudorandom numbers.

Although these methods can produce sequences of numbers that appear random, they are not truly random. This is because they are generated using a formula, and it is possible for someone to figure out the formula and predict the next number in the sequence.

In some cases, truly random numbers are needed, such as when generating passwords or encrypting data. In these cases, computers can use external sources of randomness, such as the movement of a mouse or the time it takes for a user to press a key, to generate truly random numbers.

Overall, it is important to remember that computers are not capable of generating truly random numbers on their own. They rely on algorithms and external sources of randomness to produce numbers that appear random.

question: when you stretch thoroughly , why does your hearing momentarily cut out ? Sometimes it can just numb the hearing considerably but more often than not my hearing goes when I stretch , like the ear hole is getting covered over or something . Explain like I'm five.

When you have a cold and these tubes get blocked off , diving under water or flying in an airplane can create pressure changes that are truly painful . You need to " pop " your ears to make it go away , or massage the Eustachians by chewing some gum . ( They are effected by moving your jaw around ) Now what does this have to do with stretching ? When you yawn , your jaw goes way back and your Eustachian tubes open up really wide . ( They 're not normally wide open , otherwise you 'd feel it in your ears every time you swallow . ) And then you pinch them off . As you pinch them off , the continued yawning and stretching actions squeeze the tissues around your ear , and your tongue will back against your nasal passage changing the air pressure in your sinus . All of this causes flutters of pressure changes within your inner ear , as you open it , seal it off , squeeze it and release . This momentary pressure in your inner ear pushes against the ear drum and messes with your ability to pick up sound waves during the stretch . Now sometimes something really awesome happens . Your ear actually has a built - in hearing aid , and it can get a feedback loop and have to reset ! There are tiny hairs ( ? ) in your inner ear that will vibrate in response to sound , amplifying it . Now , just like when someone gets that horrible feedback squeal between a microphone and speakers , sometimes these hairs pick up a random vibration and runaway with it . You 'll actually hear a very high - pitched ringing that slowly fades away to silence , with diminished hearing ability for a few minutes until the system has reset . Stretching sometimes sets off this feedback loop of hearing - aid hairs and can cause you to lose hearing volume for a couple minutes . More commonly you may just need to " pop " your ears after yawning to release any pressure that did n't come back out . ( Do this by pushing your jaw back and swallowing ) ( Ninja edit for clarity )

3. Control: When a spacecraft returns to Earth, it needs to be able to control its descent and land in a specific location. This is not possible when landing in a lake, as the spacecraft would be at the mercy of the wind and currents. 
4. Recovery: Finally, it would be very difficult to recover a spacecraft that has landed in a lake. Specialized equipment would be needed to lift it out of the water, which could be time-consuming and costly. 
In summary, landing a spacecraft in a lake is not a safe or practical option. Instead, spacecraft are designed to land on solid ground, where they can touch down at a controlled speed and be easily recovered.

question: How do films played at a frame rate higher than intended remain synced with the audio ? Say a movie recorded at 24 fps is played back at 60fps , either analog or through digital streaming , how does the sound keep up without being distorted ? Explain like I'm five.

They are running alongside with a time stamp that the player can use to sync the video up against the audio . It just receives both , waits until the display time and show the image and play the sound . If you are inserting more video frames , it does n't really matter , as you have to give them new time stamps that fit in between where the existing video frames were . The audio track of the movie is not affected by this process, so it will still be played back at the same rate it was recorded. This means that the audio and the video will be slightly out of sync, with the audio running slightly ahead of the video.

To fix this, the movie's audio track can be sped up slightly, so that it matches the faster frame rate of the video. This will cause the video to appear slightly slower, but the audio and video will be in sync.

question: How hydropower does n't violate the law of conservation of energy . To clarify a little . If I have two identical waterfalls and I put a wheel in one of them to generate electricity , what does that waterfall lose over the other one ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: The hydropower waterfall 's water will hit the ground with less force ( having been decelerated by the generator ) , so you might have different ( lower energy ) kinds of river formations from the hydropower waterfall . I have no idea what a slower river looks like vs a faster one , but that would be the answer .
chatgpt_answers:
Hydropower doesn't violate the law of conservation of energy because it converts one form of energy into another. When water falls from a height, it has gravitational potential energy. As it falls, this energy is converted into kinetic energy, which is the energy of movement.

When you put a wheel in a waterfall to generate electricity, the kinetic energy of the falling water is used to turn the wheel. This energy is then converted into electrical energy, which can be used to power homes and businesses.

The waterfall doesn't lose any energy in this process. Instead, the energy is simply changed from one form (kinetic energy) into another form (electrical energy). The total amount of energy remains the same, it is just being converted from one form to another.

So, if you have two identical waterfalls and you put a wheel in one of them to generate electricity, both waterfalls will have the same amount of energy. The difference is that the waterfall with the wheel will be using some of its energy to turn the wheel and create electricity, while the other waterfall will not be doing this.

question: How to ' hot fixes ' in video games work ? How can developers edit code without causing un update ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: There are two possibilities : 1 . The hotfix is applied to the server - side code which does not require a client - side update ( on the user end ) . It 's not the case that developers can choose whether a hotfix is applied on the server - side or client - side code — rather it 's based on where the bug , error , or vulnerability that needs to be corrected exists . 2 . The hotfix is silently downloaded and installed automatically when the user opens the game without the end user 's knowledge . This is how many modern software applications — especially web browsers — keep users up to date with the latest hotfixes / patches .
chatgpt_answers:
Hot fixes in video games work by allowing developers to make small changes or fixes to a game without the need to release a full update. This is often done to fix bugs or other issues that have been discovered after the game has been released.

To make a hot fix, the developers will identify the specific code that needs to be changed and then write new code to fix the problem. This new code is then tested to make sure it works as intended and does not cause any additional issues.

Once the hot fix is ready, it is then sent to the servers that host the game. These servers will then update the game with the new code, which will be downloaded by players the next time they launch the game.

Overall, hot fixes allow developers to quickly and easily fix problems in their games without the need to release a full update. This helps keep the game running smoothly and ensures that players can continue to enjoy the game without any major disruptions.

question: With Mt. Everest growing at a rate of two inches per year would the peak eventually reach space ? What are the limits on something like this ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: It would collapse under its own weight before it could reach that height . The limiting factors are the strength of the material comprising the mountain to resist deformation , versus the force gravity exerts on the mass of the mountain . As it grows , the weight of the mountain eventually deforms the material underneath it . This is essentially why large bodies like planets are spheres , instead of wacky shapes extending into space .
chatgpt_answers:
Mount Everest is the highest mountain in the world, with a peak that reaches an elevation of about 29,029 feet (8,848 meters) above sea level. It is not actually growing in height, but rather, it is being uplifted by the movement of the Earth's crust. This process is called tectonic uplift, and it occurs when the Earth's plates collide and push against each other. 
As for whether the peak of Mount Everest could eventually reach space, the answer is no. The Earth's atmosphere extends about 62 miles (100 kilometers) above the surface of the Earth, and the peak of Mount Everest is much shorter than that. Even if Mount Everest were to continue to be uplifted at a rate of two inches per year, it would take many thousands of years for it to reach the edge of the atmosphere. 
There are also other factors that limit the height that a mountain can reach. For example, the weight of the mountain itself can cause it to sink down into the Earth's crust. Additionally, erosion caused by wind and water can gradually wear away at the mountain, causing it to become shorter over time. 
So, to sum it up, Mount Everest is not going to grow tall enough to reach space. It is being uplifted by the movement of the Earth's plates, but there are other factors that limit its height and prevent it from growing indefinitely.

question: Can every single thing a computer does be broken down into binary code ? When I say every single thing , I am talking about what 's displayed on the monitor . Obviously the electronic signals are nt in binary . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ... the signals going to the monitor are in binary . Once inside the monitor , the signals get reinterpreted by the controller ciruits , in binary and determine the brightness of each color pixel , whose data is in binary . The pixels themselves are sent binary signals . The brightness of the pixel is controlled by how long the pixel is pulsed at ON state vs OFF state .
chatgpt_answers:
Yes, every single thing that a computer does can be represented in binary code. Binary code is a way of representing information using only two digits: 0 and 1. These digits are called "bits".

Every computer program, every image on the screen, every piece of data that the computer processes is represented using a series of 0s and 1s. For example, a letter of the alphabet can be represented using 8 bits (a "byte"). The letter "A" might be represented as 01000001, and the letter "B" might be represented as 01000010.

Even though the electronic signals that a computer uses to communicate are not in binary, they can still be translated into binary code by the computer's hardware. This allows the computer to understand and process the information that is being sent to it.

So, to answer your question: everything that a computer does can be represented in binary code, which is a series of 0s and 1s. The computer uses these 0s and 1s to understand and process information, just like we use letters and numbers to understand and communicate with each other.

question: Why do cameras take blurry photos ? Does it have to do with the shutter time ? Why do cameras need a shutter time in the first place ? Edit : Thanks guys ! Especially /u / Teotwawki69 for the aperture / exposure time examples Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Yes , it does have to do with the shutter speed . Shutter speed is the amount of time the shutter is open which allows light to come in contact with the image sensor ( or film ) . An image becomes blurry when the shutter is open long enough that the object and/or the camera move . A short shutter speed is necessary to get non - blurry action shots ( like sports photos ) . The trade of is that when the shutter is only for a short amount of time only a minimal amount of light comes in contact with the image sensor so you need to have good lighting . Since the vast majority of cameras automatically choose shutter speed , ISO , and other settings you will notice that taking pictures at night often leads to blurry pictures . This is because the camera knows that it will need to leave the shutter open longer to allow more light in and this means you are much more likely to move the camera while the shutter is open , causing a blur . Generally , you will need a tripod for any shutter speeds slower than 1/60th of a second .
chatgpt_answers:
Cameras take blurry photos for a variety of reasons. One reason is that the camera is not held steady enough while the picture is being taken. This can happen if the camera is hand-held and the person taking the picture is not holding it steady enough, or if the camera is resting on a surface that is not stable.

Shutter speed is the length of time that the camera's shutter is open to allow light to reach the camera's sensor. Aperture is the size of the opening in the lens that allows light to pass through to the camera's sensor. The combination of the two controls the amount of light that enters the camera and the depth of field (the area in focus) in the final photograph.

Shutter speed and aperture are important because they allow the photographer to control the amount of light that enters the camera and to freeze or blur motion in the photograph. For example, if you want to take a picture of a moving object and you want the object to appear sharp and in focus, you would need to use a fast shutter speed. This would allow the camera to quickly "freeze" the motion of the object and prevent it from appearing blurry. On the other hand, if you want to intentionally blur the motion of the object, you would use a slower shutter speed.

I hope this helps to explain why cameras take blurry photos and why shutter speed and aperture are important in photography. Let me know if you have any other questions.

question: How are allergies able to be acquired as people get older ? I 've have friends who have just started to be allergic to some foods that they were n't allergic to before . How does this happen ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Allergies are caused by our immune system mistaking food or innocuous particles like pollen , for invading pathogens . How does this happen ? Well , all cells and viruses have chemical markers on their surfaces call Antigens . Our own cells can recognize each other by reading their antigens , and our immune cells are the same . When an immune cell encounters another object , it will read its antigens , and if it does n't recognize them as friendly , it will attempt to destroy the object . The immune system is also adaptable , and it has a memory . When we get chicken pox for example , after defeating it , the system will keep a record of the chicken pox antigens , so when the disease is encountered later on in life , our immune system already knows how to fight it . Things that cause allergies also have antigens , and sometimes our immune system will encounter an antigen on some food , and mistakenly think its an invading pathogen . The immune system then mobilizes , attacks the foodstuff , and then keeps a record of its antigens . When the food is next encountered , the immune system will recognize it , and unleash its power to attack the food . The side effects of this battle is what we know as an allergy . Because our immune system can make a mistake at any point in our life , we always retain the chances of developing new allergies .
chatgpt_answers:
Allergies occur when the body's immune system mistakenly identifies a normally harmless substance as a harmful invader. When this happens, the body mounts an immune response to the substance, which can cause symptoms such as sneezing, itching, and difficulty breathing.

People can develop allergies at any age, and it is not uncommon for people to develop allergies to substances they were not previously allergic to. This can happen because the body's immune system changes over time, and a person may become more sensitive to certain substances as they age.

It is also possible for a person to develop an allergy to a substance they have been exposed to for the first time. For example, if someone has never eaten peanuts before, and they eat peanuts for the first time as an adult, they may develop an allergy to peanuts.

In summary, allergies can develop at any age, and they can be caused by either a change in the body's immune system or by exposure to a new substance.

question: What does a pharmacist actually do ? When I go to get a prescription filled , what does the pharmacist do behind the counter ? Does he mid powders to make my pills or does he just have a bottle that he counts pills from ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: I 've had quite a bit of a discussion with my pharmacist friends about what the hell they do , because I see them as largely irrelevant . But they are n't entirely . Doctors do n't really know shit about medications and get this part of your treatment wrong ALL THE TIME . My pharmacist friends ( not technicians , mind you ) have a lot to say about shithead doctors and the mistakes they make . This is what pharmacists specialize in . They will adjust dosages and look for drug reactions and conflicts . Pharmacists are most useful , in my eyes , as consultants for your doctor , because if you 're like me , you trust your doctor , you go to your doctor , if you have questions , you talk to your doctor , if you 're going to do anything , or change anything , you consult your doctor . He is your goto guy . Why am I talking to a pharmacist ? If he tells me of the conflict , I 'm just going to go to my doctor about it . As a consultant to a doctor , they can do deep thinking and reasoning about scheduling your medication and making you well , and this is far more than what a computer can do , if medication dispensing was automated ( which is mostly is for the pharmacist , because they 're more valuable for their ability to reason than their ability to mechanically lookup a drug conflict ) . What sucks is the division of intrest through the pharmacy . You see , the pharmacy exists so that doctors are inclined to perscribe the appropriate medication to suit your needs , as opposed to what would make them the most money if they sold you medications directly . It is in this separation of interest that we interact with pharmacists and their technicians in what I argue is less valuable , because of my trust and relationship with my doctor , who understands my condition and diagnosis .
chatgpt_answers:
A pharmacist is a healthcare professional who is trained to dispense medications to patients. When you go to the pharmacy to get a prescription filled, the pharmacist will first check to make sure that the medication you have been prescribed is safe and appropriate for you. They will also verify that the dosage is correct and that the medication will not interact with any other medications you are currently taking.

To dispense the medication, the pharmacist may do one of several things. If the medication is in a bottle, they may simply count out the required number of pills and put them in a bag for you. If the medication needs to be prepared in some other way, such as mixing powders together or preparing a liquid solution, the pharmacist will do this in a sterile environment to ensure that the medication is safe to take.

The pharmacist will also provide you with important information about how to take the medication, such as the correct dosage and frequency, and any potential side effects or precautions you should be aware of. They may also answer any questions you have about your medication or your overall health.

question: Magnetic Resonance Imaging ( MRI ) How does it work ? Most other explanations I found were n't too ' explanatory ' ... Pls halp Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Consider that the majority of your body is composed of water . MRIs rely on that fact . Now imagine an MRI machine as a giant magnet with an image capture device . Once you are placed inside of it , the magnet is turned on . This sends a bunch of energy into the water , and causes all of the water molecules in your body to rotate out of whatever position they were in and change into another orientation . Then the magnet is turned off . Now all of the water reverts to its original position and releases that energy placed into it by the magnet . Now the MRI machine absorbs that released energy into an image capture device and forms a picture based on the location of that water . The details of the image made of your body are produced because the water in certain tissues releases its energy at different speeds . Edit : MRIs are extremely safe as long as there is no metal in the room , which will be attracted to the powerful magnet . Also , unlike x - rays and cat scans , they do not increase your risk of cancer because they do not use ionizing radiation . Edit 2 : This is a very ELI5 explanation -- there are more complete ones elsewhere in this thread .
chatgpt_answers: Magnetic Resonance Imaging, or MRI, is a medical imaging technique that uses a large magnet and radio waves to create detailed pictures of the inside of the body. It's used to help doctors diagnose and treat a variety of medical conditions.Here's how it works:You lie on a table that slides into a long, narrow tube-like machine.The machine sends radio waves into your body. These waves are absorbed by the water in your cells, causing the atoms inside to vibrate.As the atoms vibrate, they produce a tiny pulse of energy.The machine has a magnet inside it that can detect this pulse of energy. It sends a signal back to a computer, which uses the information to create an image of the inside of your body.The computer creates a detailed picture of the inside of your body by combining information from many different pulses of energy.MRI is a safe and painless way to create detailed images of the inside of your body. It's often used to look at the brain, spine, and other internal organs. It can help doctors diagnose problems, such as injuries, tumors, and other medical conditions.

question: Why was the Hammer and Anvil tactic developed by Alexander The Great so effective ? How was it able to completely destroy the Persian army in the Battle of Issus when Alexander 's forces were completely outnumbered 5 to 1 ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: In regards to the Battle of Issus specifically , there 's a rather easy answer to why it was so effective . By the time Alexander led his Calvary ( the hammer ) into the back of the Persian lines , he had already sent the opposing commander Darius fleeing for his life . He was actually trying to chase him down , when he saw his center was in trouble , wheeled his Calvary back towards the battle , and hit the Persian center from the rear . Also , when he crashed into the Persian center , he was actually attacking a majority of the Greek Mercenaries who had been placed in the center before battle commenced , not just the Persian infantry . Once the mercenaries ( and Persians ) realized that Darius was fleeing and the battle was lost , they all began to retreat themselves . Also of note is that historians have revised numbers showing that the Persians had a 2.5 to 1 advantage . Still significant , but not as great as originally thought . TL;DR version : It worked because Darius had already fled the field , and the Persians and mercenaries realized this about the same time that Alexander unexpectedly hit them in the rear with his Calvary .
chatgpt_answers:
The Hammer and Anvil tactic is a military strategy in which one force (the hammer) attacks an enemy head-on, while another force (the anvil) waits in a position to block the enemy's retreat or escape. This can be very effective because it traps the enemy in between the two forces, making it difficult for them to escape or maneuver.

Alexander the Great was a skilled military commander who was famous for his ability to outmaneuver and defeat larger enemy forces. In the Battle of Issus, he used the Hammer and Anvil tactic to great effect by positioning his own forces to block the Persian army's retreat. This meant that the Persians were unable to escape or maneuver, and they were eventually defeated by Alexander's forces.

It's also worth noting that while the Persians may have been outnumbered 5 to 1 in the Battle of Issus, Alexander's forces were well-trained and disciplined, while the Persians were less cohesive and less well-organized. This may have also contributed to Alexander's victory in the battle.

question: How does a ranked voting system work ? I keep hearing that it is better the USA 's current system of voting but how so ? And how would it help eliminate the 2 party system ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: It depends on the system . Some use an instant runoff , where if nobody has a majority , the candidate with the most number of first place votes is eliminated , and those ballots are reallocated according to their second places votes . The process is completed until someone has a majority . It would help minor parties because the major parties spend a lot of time campaigning against the other party , and telling people that if they do n't vote for their guy , it 's like voting for the other guy . Let 's take a look at this upcoming election . Trump , Clinton and Johnson will be on the ballot in every state . So , maybe you do n't like Clinton , but you really , really do n't like Trump . You might be motivated to vote for Johnson , but you do n't want to risk Trump winning . So , you vote for Clinton . The third party gets marginalized because of this . If you get to rank the ballots , you can safely vote for the candidate that most closely matches your views . In the above scenario , you could rank Johnson first , and Clinton second . Then , even if ( well , when ) Johnson comes in third , the votes are n't wasted -- they all get reallocated to the second choice . This plan is good for third parties , but bad for the two dominant parties , because they run the risk of one of them coming in * third * when they ca n't scare voters into not voting for a third party .
chatgpt_answers: A ranked voting system is a way of casting and counting votes in an election where voters are able to rank the candidates in order of preference. Instead of just choosing one candidate, voters can indicate their top choice, second choice, third choice, and so on.In a ranked voting system, if a candidate wins a majority of first-choice votes, they are declared the winner just like in a normal election. If no candidate wins a majority of first-choice votes, then the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated and their votes are redistributed to the voters' next choice. This process is repeated until one candidate has a majority of votes and is declared the winner.One advantage of ranked voting is that it can help ensure that the winner of an election has the support of a majority of voters, rather than just a plurality of voters. In a normal election, it is possible for a candidate to win with less than 50% of the vote if there are more than two candidates running. In a ranked voting system, this is less likely to happen because the votes of the least popular candidate can be redistributed to the voters' next choice.As for how a ranked voting system could help eliminate the two-party system, it's important to note that ranked voting is just one of many potential reforms that could help encourage more political diversity. However, ranked voting could potentially help by making it easier for third-party candidates or independent candidates to win elections. Since voters are able to rank multiple candidates in order of preference, they can choose to support a third-party candidate as their first choice while still expressing a preference for one of the major party candidates as their second choice. This could make it more likely that a third-party candidate could win an election, or at least have a stronger influence on the outcome.
